**Lecturer: Kelachukwu Iheanetu (Kela)** (kela.iheanetu@ru.ac.za)

### **Problem Set 1 (25 marks) Due data is 13/07/2025**

_Double click on the Student name below to type in your names and student number_

Often times scientists, sociologists, businessmen and different government units want to understand the behavior of two or more parameters in one or more of their systems. You, the mathematician, can be of great help in this area. If we have an already existing theory that describes this system well, then you can try to fit this model to the data. Otherwise, you will need to develop/design a model that best describes the data.

***Why do we want to model data?***

**-** To understand the behaviour of the dependent  and independent variables in a given set of data

**-** To make future informed predications of the system using our model.

**-** To combine different systems together for higher productivity.

## $$\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad y= mx + c \qquad\qquad \qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad     (1)$$  

## $$y=Ae^{-Bx} + C \qquad \qquad \qquad\qquad\qquad  (2)$$

 ### $$OR \qquad \qquad \qquad\qquad\qquad$$

## $$y=Ae^{Bx} + C \qquad \qquad \qquad\qquad\qquad  (3)$$

 ### $$OR \qquad \qquad \qquad\qquad\qquad$$

## $$y=Ae^{Bx} + x \qquad \qquad \qquad\qquad\qquad  (4)$$


### All these equations will be applied to model data in this problem set but remember that you can transform an exponential equation (5) to a linear equation:
## $$y=Ae^{Bx} \qquad \qquad \qquad\qquad\qquad \qquad  (5)$$  
### by taking the log of both sides of the equation as:
### $$ ln(y) = ln(Ae^{Bx}) = ln(A) + ln(e^{Bx}) = ln(A) + Bx\rm{ln}(e)$$
## $$ ln(y) = Bx +  \rm{ln}(A) $$
### Where from equation (1)
## $y \equiv \rm{ln}(y) $, $\qquad\qquad m \equiv B\qquad\qquad$ and
### y-intercept, $c \equiv \rm{ln}(A)$
## **Note:** $C$ is not equivalent to $A$ but $ln(A)$
## $ A = e^c $
## $A = \rm{Antilog}(C)$ or A = log$^{-1}(C)$

# Import libraries
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
from scipy.optimize import curve_fit
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

### Modelling a simple linear data

First you visualise the data to see the trend of the data

Let us start by modelling the data ***yData*** below

fig, axes = plt.subplots(figsize=(16,8))
plt.plot(x, yData, 'o', label='Data 1')           # Plot data
plt.xlabel('x', fontsize=22)                      # x-axis label
plt.ylabel('y', fontsize=22)
plt.show()
### Python model of a linear equation
linear = lambda x, m, c: m * x + c  # implementation of linear model - equation (Equ (1))

x = np.array(x)                                    # Convert to Numpy.float64

popt, pcov = curve_fit(linear, x[::], yData[::]) # perform a least-square curve fits to data
# popt, pcov = curve_fit(linear, x[::6], yData[::6]) # perform a least-square curve fits to data

fig, axes = plt.subplots(figsize=(16,8))     # prepare to plot graphs
plt.subplot(1,1,1)
plt.plot(x, yData, 'o', label='Data 1')           # Plot data
plt.plot(x, linear(x, *popt), label='Model 1')    # Plot model

#plt.title(r'$y = %.2f\pm %.2f x %.2f\pm %.2f$'%(tuple(parameters)), fontsize=30) # Show the derived model
plt.title(r'$y = %.2f x %.2f \qquad\qquad m = %.2f$; C = %.2f'\
          %(popt[0],popt[1],popt[0],popt[1]), fontsize=30)

plt.xlabel('x', fontsize=22)                      # x-axis label
plt.ylabel('y', fontsize=22)                      # y-axis label

plt.legend(fontsize=26)                           # legend
plt.show()
print('m = %.2f$ \t C = %.2f' %tuple(popt)) ## round off to 2 decimal digits
print('m = %0.2f'%popt[0],' \t C = %0.2f'%popt[1])  # round off to 2 decimal digits

def expfunc1(x, a, b): # python implementation of Exponential equation (Equ (5))
